subject: RE: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I dump Java classes using javap and the bcelifier.  I also sometimes write code using BCEL. ... Of course. All names used are in the constant pool.  The
messageBody:
On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:

> >>> Look at the bytecode. Whenever you call
> >>>
> > com.funnyfarm.toplevel.deeper.deeperstill.getondown.WeAreFinallyTher
> >>> e,
> >>> it's in the bytecode, each and every character.
...
> How did you look at it?

I dump Java classes using javap and the bcelifier. I also sometimes write
code using BCEL.

> > http://java.sun.com/docs/books/vmspec/2nd-edition/html/Compiling.doc.html#14787
> >>
> >> and I do not think the method name is used every time a method is
> >> called, just an index to the method.
...
> Did you take a look at the document? It seems actually to *specify* that
> the method name *is not* encoded every where the method is called. To
> me, this argument carries some weight...

Of course.

All names used are in the constant pool. The index is an index into the
constant pool. If you are referring to something not within the
compilation unit, the name must be fetched and examined byte by byte.
If you are referring to a local name, things can be done entirely in
terms of indices, just as references to stack variables do not involve
the use of names.

Interpretation cannot be avoided if you use interfaces, abstraction,
and operations like instanceof.

--
